p: The study was conducted in the state of Himachal Pradesh (30° 22′ 40″–33° 12′ 40″ N to 75° 45′ 55″–79° 04′ 20″ E) that falls in the western Himalayan region in north India. The state covers an area of 55,673 km 2 representing 9% of the IHR. The State is bordered by Jammu and Kashmir on North, Punjab on West and South-West, Haryana on South, Uttarakhand on South-East, and China on the East (Fig. 1). It supports a hilly and mountainous terrain with all possible natural and physical features to support significant biodiversity that is used intensively by local communities for various socio-economic purposes. In view of significant dependence on NTFPs, this sector has been undertaken for investigation in the present study.
